Package sprouts.impl

Class PropertyLens<A extends @Nullable java.lang.Object,​T extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>

  • java.lang.Object
    • sprouts.impl.PropertyLens<A,​T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the value, which is expected to be an immutable data carrier, such as a record, value object, or a primitive.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Observable, Val<T>, Var<T>
    public final class PropertyLens<A extends @Nullable java.lang.Object,​T extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Var<T>
    The Sprouts Property Lens is based on the Lens design pattern, which is a functional programming technique used to simplify the process of accessing and updating parts of a nested (immutable) data structures into a new instance of the data structure. It is essentially a pair of functions, one to get a value from a specific part of a data structure (like a record), and another to set or update that value while producing a new instance of the data structure. This pattern is particularly useful with Java records, which are immutable by design, as it allows for clean and concise manipulation of deeply nested fields without breaking immutability.

    Now what does this have to do with Sprouts properties? After all, the MVVM properties of this library are mutable wrapper types with regular getter and setter methods. Although properties are mutable, their items are expected to be immutable data carriers, such as ints, doubles, strings or records. In case of records (or other custom value oriented data types), there is really no limit to how deeply nested the data structure can be. You may even want to model your entire application state as a single record composed of other records, lists, maps and primitives.

    This is where the Property Lens comes in:
    You can create a lens property from any regular property holding an immutable data structure, and then use the lens property like a regular property.
    Under the hood the lens property will use the lens pattern to access and update the nested data structure of the original property.

      • id

        public final java.lang.String id()
        Returns the name/id of the property which is useful for debugging as well as persisting their state by using them as keys for whatever storage data structure one chooses.
        For example, when converting a property based model to a JSON object, the id of the properties can be used as keys in the JSON object.
        Specified by:

      • allowsNull

        public final boolean allowsNull()
        A property will only allow null items if it was constructed with a "ofNullable(..)" factory method. Otherwise, it will throw an IllegalArgumentException when trying to set a null reference. This flag cannot be changed after the property has been constructed!
        The purpose of this method is to warn the UI that this property can contain null items, so that it may throw an exception or do something else to handle this case. For many types of properties null is simply nonsensical, like String for example, where the absence of a value is represented by an empty string.
        Specified by:
        allowsNull in interface Val<A extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Returns:
        true, if this property can contain null, false otherwise.

      • onChange

        public Var<T> onChange​(Channel channel,
                       Action<Val<T>> action)
        Description copied from interface: Var
        Use this to register an observer lambda for a particular Channel, which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Val changes through the Var::set(Channel, T) method. The lambda will receive the current item of this property. The default channel is From.VIEW_MODEL, so if you use the Var::set(T) method then the observer lambdas registered through this method will be called.
        Specified by:
        onChange in interface Val<A extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Specified by:
        onChange in interface Var<A extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Parameters:
        channel - The channel from which the item is set.
        action - The lambda which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Var changes.
        Returns:
        The Val instance itself.

      • fireChange

        public final Var<T> fireChange​(Channel channel)
        Triggers all observer lambdas for the given Channel. Change listeners may be registered using the Val.onChange(Channel, Action) method. Note that when the Var::set(T) method is called then this will automatically translate to fireChange(From.VIEW_MODEL). So it is supposed to be used by the view to update the UI components. This is in essence how binding works in Swing-Tree.
        Specified by:
        fireChange in interface Val<A extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Parameters:
        channel - The channel from which the item is set.
        Returns:
        The Val instance itself.

      • set

        public final Var<T> set​(Channel channel,
                        T newItem)
        This method provides the ability to modify the state of the wrapper from a custom channel of your choice, usually one of the channels defined in From. It might have several effects depending on the implementation.
        Specified by:
        set in interface Var<A extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Parameters:
        channel - The channel from which the item is set.
        newItem - The new item which ought to replace the old one.
        Returns:
        This very wrapper instance, in order to enable method chaining.

        Parameters:
